body: @tcondie @markusweimer
I have open REEF-2002 for this pull request and assigned it to Tyson. This pull request should be updated to REEF-2002. REEF-335 is the parent JIRA for all work removing managed C++ from the bridge.

I pulled this request locally onto my windows build machine and am seeing the same build error

[INFO] --- apache-rat-plugin:0.11:check (validate) @ reef-experimental ---
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-antrun-plugin:1.8:run (exec-protoc) on project reef-bridge-proto-java: An Ant BuildException has occured: Execute failed: java.io.IOException: Cannot run program "E:\reef\lang\java\reef-bridge-proto-java\target\protoc-3.5.1-windows-x86_64.exe" (in directory "E:\reef\lang\java\reef-bridge-proto-java"): CreateProcess error=2, The system cannot find the file specified
[ERROR] around Ant part ...<exec failonerror="true" executable="${protoc.filepath}">... @ 14:60 in E:\reef\lang\java\reef-bridge-proto-java\target\antrun\build-main.xml
[ERROR] -> [Help 1]
[ERROR]
[ERROR] To see the full stack trace of the errors, re-run Maven with the -e switch.
[ERROR] Re-run Maven using the -X switch to enable full debug logging.
[ERROR]
[ERROR] For more information about the errors and possible solutions, please read the following articles:
[ERROR] [Help 1] http://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/MAVEN/MojoExecutionException
[ERROR]
[ERROR] After correcting the problems, you can resume the build with the command
[ERROR]   mvn <goals> -rf :reef-bridge-proto-java
@tyclintw , @singlis What's the status of this PR? Updated for another round of reviews?
LGTM, will test and merge.
Thanks for the ping, I just responded.
@singlis PR updated.
Build failure is due to lack of Apache copyrights in generated file. Will fix.
Moving to REEF-2002

@dougmsft  as requested, I have moved this work over to a new branch based on REEF-2002

@markusweimer FYI
This is a preview for comments.
I am going to test and if successful pull this request into the REEF-335 branch later today.
Testing both Linux and Windows.

The java build and tests were successful on windows. On Linux I get the following error which I am rerunning.

java.io.IOException: Cannot run program "/bin/java" (in directory "./REEF_LOCAL_RUNTIME/Node-1-1523915326928"): error=2, No such file or directory
	at java.lang.ProcessBuilder.start(ProcessBuilder.java:1048)
	at org.apache.reef.runtime.local.process.RunnableProcess.run(RunnableProcess.java:196)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
Caused by: java.io.IOException: error=2, No such file or directory
	at java.lang.UNIXProcess.forkAndExec(Native Method)
	at java.lang.UNIXProcess.<init>(UNIXProcess.java:247)
	at java.lang.ProcessImpl.start(ProcessImpl.java:134)
	at java.lang.ProcessBuilder.start(ProcessBuilder.java:1029)
	... 2 more

Exception in thread "ProcessContainer:Node-1-1523915326928" java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.reef.runtime.local.process.RunnableProcess.run(RunnableProcess.java:213)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)

Both builds also produce this file now:

lang/java/reef-bridge-proto-java/dependency-reduced-pom.xml
Both the Java and C# builds and tests are successful on windows so I am going to pull it into the branch. You should take a look at the Linux build.
@dougmsft, @tcondie: This, as well as #1447 contain the same `.proto` files. Can we pull them out into their own PR to merge first?
You can close this as I have pull it into apache  REEF-335. Looks auto close on pull only works for master.
I have addressed the review comments, but there is some changes need before it can be pulled.
Closing as per @dougmsft request.
Check if we need another round review or we are good to merge.
@homezcx  Please give me a few more hours, I'll do the last round of review and merge it right away if everything looks good.
The .proto files went in with REEF-2002 which was Tyson's pr. @markusweimer .
The current build errors are also seen in other outstanding PRs so I believe this is ready to go into REEF-335. @tcondie.
@dougmsft Can you close this PR since this change is no longer needed?
@markusweimer All pending changes are in and ready for final review .

@tcondie The short answer to your question is that msbuild has its own standards for how builds should be set;up. Trying to go against those standards causes problems for users of our projects so I try to follow them whether I like them or not. In this case trying to put generated files outside the project t;ree will cause pain for users who add new .proto files as they will have add a reference to all generated files and insert a line that tells  msbuild the file to be included is outside of the project tree. Scott Inglis may have some insight on this.

@homezcx  - Sorry I missed this, but your PR failed the build. Please take a look at the AppVeyor logs to get the details. 

So I believe what is happening is that we had the project change and you added some dependencies to the Client.csproj, but the build is now using Client.DotNet.csproj. Please update the Client.DotNet.csproj with the Azure.Batch dependency + any other needed libraries.

@markusweimer @tcondie @dougmsft 
I believe you can add a reference outside of the project directory through a relatively new dotnet feature that I found from a pull request:
https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/1246

Per the check-in comments, you would use something like this in the csproj file which would allow for inclusion of all cs files without having to specify each file directly.
`<Compile` Include="..\Shared\**\*.cs" LinkBase="Shared" />

I haven't tested this  - so I don't know for sure if this would work with msbuild. 

What is the reason for the generated code to live outside the project? Is this shared between projects? And are we advocating for not checking in generated code? 

Some benefits of keeping the code in the project directory and checked in is that I can see directly what project references the code and where the code is defined. A lot of developers tend to navigate code via github, so having it online is a useful reference to have.

Since this is a check-in to a branch, lets commit this and then file a jira to address any outstanding issues on how the code generation is handled. We can definitely resolve before going into master.

@dougmsft said:
> The short answer to your question is that msbuild has its own standards for how builds should be set;up. Trying to go against those standards causes problems for users of our projects so I try to follow them whether I like them or not. 

I am not convinced that code generation during the build is against the standards of msbuild. There is a [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/15670690/how-to-add-a-command-line-code-generator-to-visual-studio) discussion on the subject which mentions the [BeforeBuild target](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms366724(v=vs.140).aspx)

> In this case trying to put generated files outside the project t;ree will cause pain for users who add new .proto files as they will have add a reference to all generated files and insert a line that tells msbuild the file to be included is outside of the project tree.

The build system of VS 2017 and .NET Core both auto-include all `.cs` files. See [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/csproj) for documentation. Also, you can add files outside the current directory structure via the following in the `.csproj`:

```xml
<ItemGroup>
  <Compile Include="../../GeneratedFromGRPC"  />
</ItemGroup>
```
[Source](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/project-json-to-csproj#files)

That being said, I am OK to commit the generated code for convenience reasons.
@markusweimer The .DotNet.csproj was already on storage 8.1.3 so no change is needed. This change brings the two projects inline with each other.
@motus @singlis DotNet.csproj updated and I can build DotNet proj in my local machine. However, Appveryor build is like queuing forever. Has been waiting for 3 hours for the build.
@tyclintw sorry to do this, but there are merge conflicts. Can you please resolve them?
Thanks Markus
@markusweimer Conflicts have been resolved.
@motus Thanks Sergiy. I have updated according to your comments and left my responses to the unchanged part.
I had to do some surgery during the merge. Hence, this commit looks as if it is from me. Sorry, @tyclintw !

@dougmsft please review.

@markusweimer FYI

@motus Updated. I have changed ```AzureBatchBootstrapREEFLauncher``` to use ```REEFEnvironment``` to launch. In this case, there will be no need to write driver.conf to disk but just to provide DriverConfiguration to ```REEFEnvironment.fromConfiguration(...)```
@shouhengyi-microsoft what do you want to do about this PR?
@motus ping.
Pulled into REEF-335 branch.

Every time I build this pr a new pom file gets generated. Is this the expected behavior?

lang/java/reef-bridge-proto-java/dependency-reduced-pom.xml

lang/java/reef-bridge-proto-java/dependency-reduced-pom.xml is generated via the shaded plugin. Looks like we can turn this off from the documentation: https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-shade-plugin/shade-mojo.html
I have pull this into my reef clone and am integrating the C# side. As I find issues I will comment.
@dougmsft added recent commits from master to this PR in order to pickup the new changes to the reef-runtime-mock, which I need for developing unit tests.
@tcondie I already pulled the updates to master into REEF-335 yesterday and then committed your changes on top of them.
This should be closed, as is. Thanks!
@dougmsft
@dougmsft please push this update, which revises the azure batch launcher implementation.

Hello,

I spent the day looking into EventCounters, and wanted to add a comment to share my findings. While I could get it to collect some data, I don't think it is completely in line with what we set out to achieve when we started building a metrics system for Reef:

- First and foremost, EventSource/EvenCounters seem to be designed for the user to define the ETW provider, so only for Windows applications. I couldn't find any examples of how event capturing was used in different OS's. 
- The above comment mentioned the viewing tool kept history; in the examples I found PerfView to be the primary tool used to view all the collected events over a timespan (is this what you meant?) The tool collects events on a specified interval, and calculates statistics on the execution times of events captured during that interval (mean, standard deviation, etc.) However, if I wanted to take these values and send them somewhere else, for example AML training service, I haven't found a way to do it easily.
- EventSource/EventCounter seem pretty confined to numbers and strings, I'm not sure there is an easy way to collect metrics of user defined types.

There were two original goals of this PR, one was to maintain a timeseries of updates of a single metrics, and the other was to support any type of metric that the user would specify. For the first one, I feel a push model is more suitable, and with help and many iterations it is finally not needing additional locks that might be a hit to performance while still preserving the entire history of updates.

Finally, to the last point, I feel this would probably be a sink implementation, where the metrics collected by MetricsService would be sent somewhere that is queryable by the user. Let me know what you think.

Thanks Mandy for the information!

So EventCounters are cross plat, they are recommended to use over the Performance counters because of that reason. They do have roots from Performance Counters, which can be a bit confusing.  Please refer to the reply here by vancem:
https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/src/System.Diagnostics.Tracing/documentation/EventCounterTutorial.md

As for PerfView, yes that is my understanding for the current toolset. For Windows, you maybe able to also use the Performance Monitor, but I haven't been able to confirm that. There should be an .net API that allows for collection of these values, please see the EventListener:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.diagnostics.tracing.eventlistener(v=vs.110).aspx
It handles a OnEventWritten function when an event is written. 

Also EventSource looks to support different types of formats looking at the EventFieldFormat enum:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.diagnostics.tracing.eventfieldformat(v=vs.110).aspx

Ok, so now looking more at this. It looks like if you use EventCounters, they will notify you when an event counter updates via the EventListener. So this is a push model. You can collect this data like you are doing now on the evaluator and submit that via the heartbeat. The driver would then aggregate this data.

Given this information, would this work? Sounds like it matches the requirements in that you would not miss a data point as you could via the pull method. Also what I like about the EventCounters is that its utilizing the .net core api. 

Let me know -- Im happy to also review what you have.

Here are a list of areas that are identified as potentially "thread-dangerous" and how it has been addressed:

**Updating metrics and creating records:**
Interlocked is used in all cases of updating metric values. I added primitive children classes to MetricBase<T> for the pirmitive type Interlocked.Exchanges(int, double, long, float), and a MetricClass<T> for reference type Interlocked.Exchange(string and other classes). Only if all of these fail will a lock(_metricLock) be used.
The updated value is then passed to the tracker to create a new record, which also records a timestamp, instead of getting the timestamp from the metric itself.

**Passing metrics from the Evaluator to the Driver:**
 - KeepUpdateRecord == true: Each tracker maintains a ConcurrentQueue(q1) of records. On the heartbeat, each tracker create a new ConcurrentQueue(q2), moves the contents of q1 to q2 one by one until q1 is empty, then passes q2 to the driver. In the meantime, new records can still be added to q1 safely.
 - KeepUpdateRecord == false: On the Evaluator side, no records will be created and q1 will be empty until the heartbeat. On the heartbeat, one single record will be created from the value held by the metric object, the record will be put in q2, then passed.

**Updating metrics received from Evaluator when multiple Evaluators try to update the same metric:**
 - KeepUpdateRecord == true: records received from the evaluator are added to the driver's ConcurrentQueue one by one.
 - KeepUpdateRecord == false: Driver's records are reassigned to the received records using Interlocked.Exchange.

**Sinking metrics on Driver side:**
 - same as Passing metrics from Evaluator to Driver

I realized that boxing and unboxing wouldn't work how I initially thought after our discussion because _typedValue variable doesn't reflect changes once it's boxed into an object, so I instead reverted back to individual primitive implementations, each with its own Interlocked.Exchange call, plus a MetricClass that takes reference type exchanges. It should be water-tight thread-safe now, let me know what you think :)
